Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] first styleable resource id is always incorrect" (#3025) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Fixes #3049

This commit also reworks the id generation of the
`ManagedResourceParser` to try replicate the
ids which `aapt2` produces. As a result if the managed
parser generates the code from the `R.txt` file or
directly from the resources, the resulting designer.cs
file will be identical most of the time. There does seem
to be an odd ordering issue where the R.txt file does
not seem to order the items by name as the Id's are 
sometimes switched.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[AAPT2] first styleable resource id is always incorrect" (#3049) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new android project. Android Options: 
- shared runtime + fast deployment
- multi dex on
- dex compiler d8
- code shrinker proguard (i'm unable to run any app when using r8 even in debug mode)
- enable debugger
- use concurrent garbage collector
- linking none
- compile with android 9
2. Create a simple android custom control, add a styleable android resource, and use the custom control in the android layout, specifying one of the styleable resource in its attributes.
```xml
Ex using the custom "MvxBind" styleable attribute.

        <TextView
            app:MvxBind="VisibilityNoAnim InvertedBool(IsInternetAvailable)"
            android:layout_width="match_parent"
            android:layout_height="wrap_content"
            android:text="InternetDisconnected"
 />
```
3. Compile and debug

```xml
<resources>
  <declare-styleable name="MvxImageView2">
    <attr name="throttle" format="integer"/>
    <attr name="imageUrl" format="string"/>
    <attr name="imageViewTraceEnabled" format="boolean"/>
    <attr name="throttleSvg" format="string"/>
  </declare-styleable>
</resources>
```

```csharp
        using R = ReproApp.Resource;

...

        [Android.Runtime.Preserve]
        public MvxImageView2(Context context, IAttributeSet attrs, int defStyleAttr, int defStyleRes) : base(context, attrs, defStyleAttr, defStyleRes)
        {
            if (attrs != null)
            {
                using (var a = context.ObtainStyledAttributes(attrs, R.Styleable.MvxImageView2, defStyleAttr, defStyleRes))
                {
                    TraceEnabled = a.GetBoolean(R.Styleable.MvxImageView2_imageViewTraceEnabled, TraceEnabled);
                    ImageLoadThrottleMilliseconds = a.GetInt(R.Styleable.MvxImageView2_throttle, ImageLoadThrottleMilliseconds);
                    ImageUrl = a.GetString(R.Styleable.MvxImageView2_imageUrl) ?? ImageUrl;
                    throttleSvg = a.GetString(R.Styleable.MvxImageView2_throttleSvg);
                    a.Recycle();
                }
            }
        }
```

```xml

<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto">

        <MvxImageView2
            app:traceEnabled="false"
            android:src="@android:drawable/ic_menu_gallery"
            android:layout_width="match_parent"
            android:layout_height="match_parent"
 />

...
```

### Expected Behavior

R.Styleable.MvxImageView2_imageViewTraceEnabled and all other constants except  R.Styleable.MvxImageView should have a value from between 0 and 3.

### Actual Behavior

All the custom styleable constants (except  R.Styleable.MvxImageView) have a value between 0 and 3 except one whose value is negative (if it was an uint, it would be over 2147483648).

Thus the constant is never found in the typedarray and the call crash the app with an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

I have reproduce the issue with the custom attributes of mvvmcross, with XamSvg, and a custom image control.

The workaround is to disable AAPT2.

### Version Information

VS2019 16.1.0 preview 2

[versioninfo.txt](https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/files/3132418/versioninfo.txt)

### Log File

```
04-30 11:50:11.080 19485 19485 I mono-stdout: (MvxBind) #1/L18:Error:java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: length=726; index=-100260048
04-30 11:50:11.080 19485 19485 I mono-stdout: (MvxBind) #1/L19:Error:   at android.content.res.TypedArray.getString(TypedArray.java:198)
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "[tests] Kill adb server before test instrumentation" (#3069) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
This will force adb to restart the server, so we should have fresh adb
for `adb shell am instrument ...`. Hopefully it will help with crashes
of `Mono.Android_Tests` test, we are seeing frequently on Jenkins.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[d16-2] Add support for deferred builds when the IDE supports them" (#3070) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
In order to take the most expensive target in a DTB (`UpdateAndroidResources`) out
of the DTB, the IDE can monitor design-time builds and schedule a deferred build
to run after the DTB finishes.

When the IDE supports deferred builds, the  `DeferredBuildSupported` will be
true, and in that case, the `DeferredBuild` target will run after the DTB finishes. To
schedule targets to run as part of that deferred build, they need to be added to
the `DeferredBuildDependsOn` property.

Targets can selectively disable themselves on DTBs when the deferred build is
supported by checking for both `'$(DeferredBuildSupported)' == 'true'` and the
`'$(DeferredBuild)' == 'true'` property, which is set for those builds.

The deferred build queuing will be based on the following condition: a regular design
time build was triggered and the targets run were either "Compile" or any target
that contains "DesignTime" in its name (this excludes queuing a deferred build
when a target like `GetFrameworkPaths` or `GetTargetPath` is run in a DTB, for
example).

Note that `Inputs`/`Outputs` on the targets, as well as any `DependsOnTargets`
specified remain the same as before. The effect is that expensive targets that caused
a slow DTB before, can now be scheduled to run *after* the build finishes (this is
when the deferred build is queued).

It's entirely opt-in (if no targets are specified for `DeferredBuildDependsOn`
it will be essentially a no-op run).

Finally, when a regular build starts, the existing deferred build will be waited for
completion before continuing, to ensure no concurrency happens.

The initial `Compile` target is run by the DTB in VS while
skipping the compiler call, at which point the UpdateAndroidResources
should also be skipped when the `DeferredBuildSupported` is `True`.

Subsequently, we run the `DeferredBuild` (or rather, the `UpdateAndroidResources`
which would be run by the `DeferredBuildDependsOn` we append it to)
which should also succeed (it's run with the same global parameters/
properties as the initial DTB).

Finally, we run the normal build, at which point everything should
succeed like before.

If an XVS version that supports this feature is installed, you can turn it on
by setting an environment variable `DeferredBuildSupported=true`. An A/B experiment
or remote setting can also set this value.

Backport of #2636.

/cc @kzu

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "F# records are broken when building with Link SDK and User Assemblies in Debug mode" (#2873) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1.  Define an F# record type
2. Set the Linking option to SDK and User Assemblies
3. Try to create an instance of the record

If you try this sample out you can see it happening. Click the FAB. 

When set to Link SDK Assemblies Only or None, you will see the record printed in the debug console.

When set to link User Assemblies, it will throw an exception.

I have tried adding the standard Preserve attribute but it hasn't helped.
I also saw errors in my production app that suggested union case constructors were being removed.

Remember to clean / rebuild between runs.

[Test.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/files/3014145/Test.zip)


### Expected Behavior

The record should be constructed normally.

### Actual Behavior

The record crashes the application when trying to access its values.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Apply round corners shape based on radius" (#6099) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description of Change ###
Apply shape treatment with corner radius settings

### Issues Resolved ### 
- fixes #5544

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug, Shell] RouteHost with capital letter throws exception" (#6093) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description
I am not sure whether this is a bug or feature request. I spend lots of time on fixing a bug. It turns out that the RouteHost name in my project has capital letters. The error message is:

**System.InvalidOperation Exception has been thrown
Shell CurrentItem should not be null**

The error message is not at all helpful in pointing to the code causing the error. It will be helpful if the xaml editor shows the error during write time. Or compiler point to the actual code in error message at compile time.
Otherwise there could be a way to allow the developers to define RouteHost in any Case.



### Basic Information

- Version with issue: Xamarin.Forms-pre10
- IDE: Visual Studio for Mac

- Affected Devices:iOS and Android

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[d16-2] Add more details to MSBuild errors for provisioning profiles" (#5987) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
A lot of apps get renamed during the build process. E.g. most of our apps have an alpha or a beta version and they have separate bundle names so that you can install them side-by-side.

I usually don't know if there is an error in my build script or if the provisioning profile is really missing on the machine I'm building on. By displaying the name, the user might notice incorrect bundle names.

Backport of #5984.

/cc @spouliot @SamuelDebruyn

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[d16-2] Fix/improve marshalling of out/ref parameters, arrays, Classes and Selectors. Fixes #5171." (#5966) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
* Share much more marshalling code between the dynamic and static registrar
  (by refactoring code into separate functions used by both).
* Fix an issue with multiple out/ref parameters in the dynamic registrar.
* Throw an error instead of silently ignoring out/ref parameter types we don't
  completely understand in the dynamic registrar.
* Fix returning Class/SEL out/ref parameters in the static registrar.
* Fix returning NSString out/ref parameters in the dynamic registrar.
* Add/fix support for out/ref arrays everywhere.
* Fix support for the various supported out/ref parameter types in the
  generator.
* Add lots of tests.

Fixes https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/issues/5171.

This pull request is best reviewed commit-by-commit.

Backport of #5963.

/cc @rolfbjarne

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[registrar] Fix marshalling of structs with a single member." (#5986) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Merged pull request "[runtime] Fix crash in the x86_64 dynamic registrar." (#5989) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
In [this][1] innocuous-looking commit I made the x86_64 dynamic registrar
crash when TRACE is defined. The underlying problem is that CallState's rsi
field is re-used as rax upon exit of the trampoline. This means that the
CallState.sel () function that gets the selector, will instead get the return
value upon exit. When TRACE is defined, we try to print the selector upon
exiting the trampoline, and since the rsi field is now the rax field, we end
up trying to print the return value as if it were a selector, and things go
slightly sideways.

[1]: https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/commit/464882d14a83

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "I'm having an timeout issue, specifically a WebException." (#5992) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- ðŸš¨ STOP ðŸš¨ ð—¦ð—§ð—¢ð—£ ðŸš¨ ð‘ºð‘»ð‘¶ð‘· ðŸš¨ -->

<!--
Please fill in the *entire* template below.
The template is designed to avoid unnecessary delays to confirm and fix reported issues. Issues with missing information generally end up with a `need-info` label and take significantly more time to fix. Please help us help you!
For more information see https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-&-Suggestions
For support requests use https://www.xamarin.com/support
-->
### Steps to Reproduce

So the issue I'm running into is a WebException (specifically a timeout).

I have been able to narrow it down to the HTTP Client implementation settings in iOS.

- When it is set to **Managed** I don't get the error

- When I set it to **NSUrlSession (iOS 7+)** a timeout exception is being generated after a request has been running longer than 1 minute.

We also tested our json request, using Insomnia, and it took about 5 mins to complete and we got data, but no exception is generated.

I do not have access to the middle tier, just the server logs that get updated.

I know about the HttpClient.Timeout property which we have set for large amount of time, are there any other configuration variables for setting the timeout when needing TLS 1.2?

(The TLS 1.2 is a requirement)

_:: Extra Info That May Be Helpful ::
It looks as though NSUrlSession (iOS 7+) setting forces the native HTTP Client to be used (which has a hard-coded timeout of 60 seconds)_

This was cross posted at Xamarin.Forms before I new where to post.

### Expected Behavior
A HTTP response, specifically a  file (size may vary)

### Actual Behavior
I get a WebException (Request timeout)

### Environment
Mac OS
- XCode 8.3.3

Visual Studio 2015 for Windows
- Xamarin 4.6.3.4
- Xamarin.IOS 10.12.3.3
